On Saturday, [[Italy]] won its third victory at the [[Eurovision]] song competition, held this year at the {{w|Rotterdam Ahoy}} arena in {{w|Rotterdam}}, [[Netherlands]].  The Italian rock band {{w|MÃ¥neskin}}'s song ''Zitti E Buoni'' won 524 points from public and professional judges.  [[France|French]] singer {{w|Barbara Pravi}}'s song ''{{w|VoilÃ  (Barbara Pravi song)|VoilÃ }}'' received 499 points, and [[Austria]]n singer {{w|Gjon's Tears}} ''{{w|Tout l'univers}}'' got 432 points; finishing second and third respectively.
[[File:Maneskin 2019.jpg|left|thumb|File photo of MÃ¥neskin.{{image|MÃ¥neskin}}]]
Out of 39 countries participating this time, 26 countries including hosts Netherlands and the Big Five â€” France, [[Germany]], Italy, [[Spain]] and the [[United Kingdom]] â€” competed in the finals.  The competition began on May 18.  Three of the Big Five, and the hosts finished at the very bottom of the vote ranking.  Netherlands got 11, Spain got 6, Germany bagged 3 and the UK received zero points.  All four received zero points from the audience.

Dutch singer {{w|Duncan Laurence}} won the 2019 edition of Eurovision in [[Tel Aviv]] winning 498 points for his song ''{{w|Arcade (song)|Arcade}}''.  That victory meant Netherlands was to host the competition 2020, which was cancelled because of "escalating spread of [[COVID-19]] throughout Europe".  This year, 3500 people were in audience, multiple reports stated.  They all were tested negative to be eligible for attending the event, Eurovision stated.

[[Iceland]]'s {{w|DaÃ°i Freyr}} could not perform live in both semi-finals and the final, having tested positive of the virus.
